docs.snippet: Eating your vegetables has never been sweeter, at least since Fauchon introduced pâte de légumes, a new line of vegetable-based confections. Like their cousins, pâte de fruits (fruit jellies), these jewel-toned, sugary squares have intense flav...
docs.abstract: Fauchon introduces pate de legumes, new line of vegetable-based confections; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Eating your vegetables has never been sweeter, at least since Fauchon introduced pâte de légumes, a new line of vegetable-based confections. Like their cousins, pâte de fruits (fruit jellies), these jewel-toned, sugary squares have intense flavors, but with beet, red pepper, fennel and carrot replacing the usual passion fruit and black currant. Imported from France, they are made using the same technique as Fauchon's pâte de fruits, substituting vegetables that are naturally high in sugar. While beet, with its magenta hue, is the most striking, the red pepper is the eye-opener. Tangy, ripe and spicy, with a dried-apricotlike vibrancy, it makes you wonder why red peppers are not used more often in desserts. Pâte de légumes are $40 a pound at Fauchon, 442 Park Avenue (56th Street), (212) 308-5919; 1000 Madison Avenue (77th Street), (212) 570-2211; and 1383 Third Avenue (78th Street), (212) 517-9600. MELISSA CLARK

headline.main: Beets and Peppers For the Candy Dish

docs.snippet: Redhawk, a Muenster-style cheese from the Cowgirl Creamery in Point Reyes Station, Calif., won the American Cheese Society's grand prize this year. It is astonishingly good: pungent and almost beefy, but smooth-textured. Cowgirl uses organic milk,...
docs.abstract: Redhawk is Muenster-style cheese from Cowgirl Creamery in Point Reyes Station, Calif; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Redhawk, a Muenster-style cheese from the Cowgirl Creamery in Point Reyes Station, Calif., won the American Cheese Society's grand prize this year. It is astonishingly good: pungent and almost beefy, but smooth-textured. Cowgirl uses organic milk, and though Redhawk is a triple-cream, it has none of the overly intense richness of that category. It is also expensive, normally selling for $28.99 a pound at the Murray's Cheese shops in Greenwich Village and at Grand Central Terminal.

headline.main: A California Cheese, Pungent and Smooth, Captures the Crown

docs.snippet: For the last few summers, Leslie Ann Nilsson, below, has run Cafe St. Bart's on the terrace at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and 50th Street. This year, instead of striking her tent, so to speak, she is staying open in the cold w...
docs.abstract: Cafe St Bart on terrace of St Bartholomew's Episcopal Church is staying open in cold weather thanks to fully enclosed and heated all-weather tent; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: For the last few summers, Leslie Ann Nilsson, below, has run Cafe St. Bart's on the terrace at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and 50th Street. This year, instead of striking her tent, so to speak, she is staying open in the cold weather, with seating for 112 in a fully enclosed and heated all-weather tent that would make Ralph Lauren proud. The tent, made of white plastic, is masked outside with greenery. Inside it has velour and birch bark on the walls, a beamed ceiling, carpets, chandeliers and even a fake fireplace, all designed by Musters & Company, a special events concern. To go with the country-style décor, the cafe has a harvest menu of dishes like pasta with butternut squash and chicken potpie.

headline.main: Park Avenue Gets Breezy in Winter, So a Cafe Throws Up a Tent

docs.snippet: The Campbell Apartment in Grand Central Terminal specializes in classic cocktails, some from the 1920's and 30's. At the small bar it has opened in a former taxi stand at the entrance to the station at 43rd Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, it has com...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Campbell Apartment in Grand Central Terminal specializes in classic cocktails, some from the 1920's and 30's. At the small bar it has opened in a former taxi stand at the entrance to the station at 43rd Street and Vanderbilt Avenue, it has come up with some new ones, themed to the location. One of them, Vanderbilt Punch, far right, is a tall, lightly sweetened refresher made with rum, Cointreau, cranberry and papaya juices, and a slice of orange.

headline.main: To Ease the Wait For the Train Or the Taxi

docs.snippet: I'll take caramel over chocolate any day, so ''Caramel,'' by Peggy Cullen (Chronicle Books, $19.95), could have been written just for me. Now is the time to bake little caramel-peach upside-down cakes and burnt-sugar and lemon tarts with blueberry...
docs.lead_paragraph: I'll take caramel over chocolate any day, so ''Caramel,'' by Peggy Cullen (Chronicle Books, $19.95), could have been written just for me. Now is the time to bake little caramel-peach upside-down cakes and burnt-sugar and lemon tarts with blueberry compote, and you will find recipes for them in the book, along with classic lace cookies, toffee and caramel corn. Marshmallow confections called Mad Caps, above, take time and patience, but are well worth it -- even though they will be eaten in a flash. Recipes for ice cream desserts with caramel topping are included, but not for caramel ice cream. There is an excellent guide to making caramel, with good safety tips. (Sugar caramelizes at 320 to 350 degrees, hot enough to burn.) Ms. Cullen wisely cautions that handling caramel is not for small children.

headline.main: Fingers Are for Licking, Not Burning

docs.snippet: Twinkies dressed like drum majors, and red, white and blue marshmallows on a stick are snacks fit for patriots of every stripe, but they are among the new treats for children from Ruby et Violette, a bakery at 457 West 50th Street. A gift bag of t...
docs.abstract: Twinkies dressed like drum majors and red, white and blue marshmallows on a stick are snacks for children at Ruby et Violette, bakery at 457 West 50th Street; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Twinkies dressed like drum majors, and red, white and blue marshmallows on a stick are snacks fit for patriots of every stripe, but they are among the new treats for children from Ruby et Violette, a bakery at 457 West 50th Street. A gift bag of two Twinkies is $7; the marshmallow sticks are $2.50 each. Oreos and Moon Pies in parade dress are also available. The treats can be ordered from www.rubyetviolette.com or from (212) 582-6720. The company donates 5 percent of its net profits to Mount Sinai Hospital's traumatic brain injury unit.

headline.main: For the Young And Patriotic, Marshmallows On Parade

docs.snippet: Plastic or vinyl place mats are on the tables at Nougatine, Craft, Blue Fin and Kitchen 82, restaurants that would never dream of using plastic glassware, dishes or flatware. Sandy Chilewich designed them for her New York company, Chilewich (prono...
docs.abstract: Plastic or vinyl place mats are on tables of several New York City restaurants; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Plastic or vinyl place mats are on the tables at Nougatine, Craft, Blue Fin and Kitchen 82, restaurants that would never dream of using plastic glassware, dishes or flatware. Sandy Chilewich designed them for her New York company, Chilewich (pronounced CHILL-a-witch), in ways that mimic linen, straw or bark-like basket weaves. All are in neutral tones from pale to dark, and are occasionally shot with colored or metallic strands.

docs.snippet: A month or so ago, a bizarre shipment of beluga from Bulgaria landed in Petrossian's New York warehouse. Instead of the usual mass of glittering charcoal-gray beads, ivory-colored caviar filled the tins. Until they are killed, sturgeon give no clu...
docs.abstract: Bulgarian beluga, from mouth of Danube, is sold by Petrossian of New York City; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: A month or so ago, a bizarre shipment of beluga from Bulgaria landed in Petrossian's New York warehouse. Instead of the usual mass of glittering charcoal-gray beads, ivory-colored caviar filled the tins. Until they are killed, sturgeon give no clue to the color of their eggs, which are usually gray to inky black and can be brownish or even gold, a color prized by czars and shahs. White caviar is the rarest. Armen Petrossian, the president of the company, which is based in Paris, knew about it and had tasted it previously. Petrossian let the Bulgarian beluga, from the mouth of the Danube, rest a few weeks, and began selling it last week. Or trying to. Customers at its shop at 911 Seventh Avenue (58th Street) are put off by the strange color, to say nothing of the price: $1,250 for 125 grams, about four ounces. Less than five pounds is available. Though they came from beluga sturgeon, the eggs are somewhat small. The flavor does not have the almost floral delicacy of most beluga but is more assertive and intriguingly smoky, as seems typical of white caviar.

headline.main: The Beluga Is Blond, and the Taste Is Sultry

docs.snippet: Barbecue grills were once ubiquitous in state parks in the Hudson Valley. But over the years they fell prey to neglect and vandalism. Now, in time for Memorial Day, they are back, but with a difference. Five designs of animal-shape cast-iron grill...
docs.abstract: Cast-iron grills shaped like animals are installed in two New York State parks for summer barbecue grilling season; are work of Pae White; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Barbecue grills were once ubiquitous in state parks in the Hudson Valley. But over the years they fell prey to neglect and vandalism. Now, in time for Memorial Day, they are back, but with a difference. Five designs of animal-shape cast-iron grills by Pae White, a Los Angeles artist, have been installed in Bear Mountain State Park, south of West Point, and in Franklin D. Roosevelt State Park in Yorktown Heights. There's an owl, a turtle, a rabbit, a fox and a frog, most with hinged covers.

headline.main: In State Parks, Friendly Animals Take to the Range

docs.snippet: Buying cheese in peak condition can be a challenge. Underripe Camembert, overly funky Teleme and dried-out goat crottins are not uncommon on restaurant cheese carts and store shelves.    Terrance Brennan, a restaurateur with a penchant for cheese,...
docs.abstract: Terrance Brennan, restaurateur, opens Artisanal Cheese Center in Manhattan, where cheeses are properly aged and shipped to mail-order customers, shops and restaurants; photo (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: Buying cheese in peak condition can be a challenge. Underripe Camembert, overly funky Teleme and dried-out goat crottins are not uncommon on restaurant cheese carts and store shelves. Terrance Brennan, a restaurateur with a penchant for cheese, wants to change that, so he has opened the Artisanal Cheese Center, an aging complex at 500 West 37th Street, where cheeses are being pampered and will be shipped to mail-order customers, shops and restaurants. The cheeses will be sold retail at Mr. Brennan's restaurant Artisanal and via a catalog and a Web site.

headline.main: A Place to Bring Cheeses To Just the Right Age
